subject: 11a 6/14 Update: Solar array retraction work, spacewalk preps on tap
body:
11a 6/14 Update: Solar array retraction work, spacewalk preps on tap



=================================

CBS NEWS STS-117 STATUS REPORT: 57
Posted: 10:43 AM, 6/14/07

By William Harwood
CBS News Space Analyst

Changes and additions:

   SR-54 (06/14/07): NASA considers shuttle mission extension if Russian computer glitch not resolved soon3`   
   SR-55 (06/14/07): Russian engineers troubleshoot computer problem; telemetry restored; false fire alarm sounds
   SR-56 (06/14/07): Computer system partially revived; troubleshooting continues
   SR-57 (06/14/07): Shuttle astronauts gear up for more solar array retraction work

=================================

10:43 AM, 6/14/07, Update: Astronauts gear up for solar array retraction; spacewalk blanket repair practice

Amid troubleshooting in Russia to recover critical space station navigation and control computers, the Atlantis astronauts face a busy day of work to continue the retraction of the P6-2B solar array, work that got off to a good start before and during a spacewalk Wednesday.

Astronauts Jim Reilly and Danny Olivas also will review plans for a spacewalk Friday and practice techniques for repairing a pulled-up insulation blanket on the shuttle's left-side Orbital Maneuvering System rocket pod.

Olivas will carry out the actual repair, anchored to the end of the shuttle's 50-foot-long robot arm. He plans to push the 4-inch by 6-inch blanket corner down and then use a surgical stapler to secure it to adjacent blankets. Both spacewalkers have time built into their schedule for additional solar array retraction work if necessary. A fourth spacewalk by Pat Forrester and Steve Swanson is scheduled for Sunday.

The P6 solar array was installed on the station in December 2000 to provide electrical power to U.S. systems during the early stages of assembly. Now that NASA is activating the station's permanent power system, P6 must be moved to the left end of the lab's solar truss.

That move is planned for later this year but first, the two 115-foot dual-blanket solar wings making up the P6 array must be retracted. One wing was stowed during a shuttle flight last December, but the astronauts ran into major problems and had to stage an unplanned spacewalk to coax the blankets back into their storage boxes.

Building on lessons learned, the Atlantis astronauts began the retraction of the other side of the P6 array Wednesday using a slow, step-by-step approach to prevent the blind-like blankets from folding the wrong way or otherwise hanging up as their framework mast is pulled in.

Before Wednesday's spacewalk, the astronauts were able to retract the central mast some 28 feet before standing down for the EVA. Then, Forrester and Swanson, using custom insulated tools, freed blanket grommets from guidewires and helped ensure smooth folding, allowing the mast to be retracted another five bays or so for a total of about 45 feet.

Working inside the space station, the astronauts plan to carry out more bay-by-bay retraction attempts today. If any blankets hang up, the crew can re-extend the mast or jog it from side to side using motors that normally help the panels track the sun. Several so-called "wiggle" tests Wednesday set up enough rippling motion in the flexible blankets to free slats that had hung up on guide wires. The astronauts are hoping for more of the same today.

Here is a timeline of today's activity (in EDT and mission elapsed time; includes rev. H of the NASA TV schedule):

EDT........DD...HH...MM...EVENT

06/14/07

08:38 AM...05...13...00...STS/ISS crew wakeup
11:38 AM...05...16...00...Station robot arm maneuvers to P6-2B retraction viewing
11:38 AM...05...16...00...EVA-3: Procedures review
11:38 AM...05...16...00...P6-2B retraction window opens
12:28 PM...05...16...50...EVA-3: Tagup with mission control
01:03 PM...05...17...25...EVA-3: Tools preparation
02:18 PM...05...18...40...EVA-3: Repair practice
03:03 PM...05...19...25...P6-2B retraction window closes
03:03 PM...05...19...25...Post-EVA tool reconfig
03:03 PM...05...19...25...Nitrogen transfer terminated
03:18 PM...05...19...40...Post EVA-2 tools config
03:33 PM...05...19...55...Crew meals begin
04:18 PM...05...20...40...Spacesuit swap
05:08 PM...05...21...30...Equipment lock preps
05:58 PM...05...22...20...EVA-3: Tools configured
06:00 PM...05...22...22...Mission status briefing on NTV
07:13 PM...05...23...35...EVA-3: Tagup with mission control
08:23 PM...06...00...45...EVA-3: Procedures review
09:58 PM...06...02...20...Fox Radio, KMGH-TV, KUSA-TV crew interviews on NTV
10:53 PM...06...03...15...EVA-3: Mack prebreathe and tool config
11:48 PM...06...04...10...EVA-3: 10.2 depress

06/15/07

12:08 AM...06...04...30...ISS crew sleep begins
12:38 AM...06...05...00...STS crew sleep begins
01:00 AM...06...05...22...Daily video highlights reel

Depending on how far the crew gets today, the flight plan includes time for additional retraction work Friday, when Olivas and Reilly stage the crew's third spacewalk.

Atlantis is scheduled to undock from the space station next Tuesday around 10:40 a.m. But the Russian computer system must be operational before the shuttle departs. Protecting their options, NASA managers today asked the astronauts to implement power conservation measures to permit a possible additional docked day if necessary.

As of 10:25 a.m., the station's power system had been successfully reconfigured after Russian engineers re-established communications and the ability to command one computer in the guidance system and one in the command-and-control system. Engineers were hopeful about restoring two other systems to operation. But it's not yet clear what triggered the original problem and troubleshooting continues.
